title: Hunt & Hess Classification of Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
desc: The Hunt & Hess Classification of Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Classifies severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage to predict mortality.

orgreference.text: Hunt WE, Hess RM. 'Surgical risk as related to time of intervention in the repair of intracranial aneurysms.' Journal of Neurosurgery 1968 Jan;28(1):14-20.

other_refer.text: Degen LA, Dorhout Mees SM, Algra A, Rinkel GJ. Interobserver variability of grading scales for aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Stroke. 2011;42(6):1546-1549.
Hunt WE, Meagher JN, Hess RM. 'Intracranial aneurysm. A nine-year study.' Ohio State Medical Journal 1966 Nov;62(11):1168-71.
Rosen DS, Macdonald RL. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Grading Scales: A Systematic Review. Neurocrit Care. 2005;2:110-118.
Lindsay KW, Teasdale GM, Knill-Jones RP. Observer variability in assessing the clinical features of subarachnoid hemorrhage. J Neurosurg. 1983;58:57-62.

Nieuwkamp DJ, Setz LE, Algra A, Linn FH, de Rooij NK, Rinkel GJ. Changes in case fatality of aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage over time, according to age, sex, and region: a meta-analysis. Lancet Neurol. 2009 Jul;8(7):635-42.

data.evidence: Selection of group of symptoms, assigned point value.
data.facts:
Criteria Value Grade Mortality
Mild Headache, Alert and Oriented, Minimal (if any) Nuchal Rigidity 1 I 30%
Full Nuchal Rigidity, Moderate-Severe Headache, Alert and Oriented, No Neuro Deficit (Besides CN Palsy) 2 II 40%
Lethargy or Confusion, Mild Focal Neurological Deficits 3 III 50%
Stuporous, More Severe Focal Deficit 4 IV 80%
Comatose, showing signs of severe neurological impairment (ex: posturing) 5 V 90%
